descript.abstract: High elevation areas, such as the Valles Caldera National Preserve (VCNP) located in the Jemez Mountains of Northern New Mexico, have been described as exceptionally vulnerable to changes in climate and thus offer an ideal window to monitor temperature changes and their possible implications. In the present study, we examined the effects diurnal and seasonal temperature changes and discharge have on water quality. Two water sampling regimes (diurnal and grab samples) were employed over a one-year time frame (May 2010-May 2011) at four sites along two potentially vulnerable headwater streams located within the VCNP. Concentrations of primary nutrients (nitrate, nitrite, and phosphate) and other solutes (bromide, chloride, fluoride, and sulfate), along with discharge and physicochemical parameters (conductivity, dissolved oxygen, pH, and turbidity) served as indices of water quality. The results of this study indicated that primary nutrients and other solutes were largely sensitive to seasonal temperature changes, but that their sensitivity was modulated by the unique characteristics of sample sites. It was concluded that the examination of the effects of seasonal water temperature fluctuations on primary nutrient and other solute concentrations can offer a deeper understanding of challenges headwater streams may face as result of anticipated climate changes.
descript.purpose: The objective of this research was to monitor the effects of water temperature on two Valles Caldera National Preserve (VCNP) headwater streams in an attempt to gain a better understanding of nutrient and other solute dynamics in association with discharge and physiochemical parameters. First, we wanted to determine the extent to which water temperature changes were related to alterations in solute concentrations, discharge, and physiochemical parameters. Second, we set to determine the influence of seasonal water temperature changes on water quality, as defined by solute concentrations, discharge, and physiochemical parameters.

procstep.procdesc: Field Methods: Two sampling regimes were implemented from May 2010 to May 2011. Diurnal sampling was performed largely during the 2010 field collection season using model 3700 portable ISCO samplers (Teledyne Technologies, Lincoln, Nebraska, USA). Samplers were programmed to simultaneously collect water samples every hour, over a 24-hour period at the four sites, once a month for nine months. In addition, bi-monthly water samples were collected manually (grab samples) from each site. Following the 2010 field collection season, water samples were collected exclusively using the grab sample method. Water samples were analyzed for biodegradable organic carbon (BDOC), dissolved organic carbon (DOC), anionic nutrients (nitrate, nitrite, and phosphate) and other anionic solute concentrations (fluoride, chloride, bromide). All water samples for nutrient analysis were stored on ice for transportation to the lab (~3 hrs.). Prior to analysis all samples were stored frozen (~≤1 week) prior to analysis. Prior to carbon sampling, all glassware was pre-sterilized. This process included: washing glassware (borosilicate vials) with detergent and rinsing it in cold water, rinsing it in 0.1N HCl followed by deionized water then wrapping glassware in aluminum and heating it in a kiln for six hours at 500°C. The 0.45-μm pore size Whatman GF/F filters used for data collection were wrapped in foil and heated in the kiln following the same procedure used for glassware. During grab sample collections, two 40 mL-grab water samples at each site were taken, a sample for measuring DOC and a sample for measuring BDOC. In the field, the DOC and BDOC samples were filtered into pre-sterilized borosilicate vials using Whatman GF/F filters with a 0.45-μm pore size. DOC samples were collected and preserved with sodium azide and stored at 4ºC prior to analysis. BDOC samples were immediately wrapped in aluminum foil and stored in the dark at 20±5ºC for 28 days following collection. Discharge in m3/s for each stream was recorded at the time of grab sample collection and during diurnal sample collection utilizing a model 201D Marsh-McBirney portable water current meter (Marsh-McBirney, Gaithersburg, Maryland, USA) and a Rickly wading rod (Rickly Hydrological, Columbus, Ohio, USA ), following standard U.S. Geological Survey methods. Additionally, physicochemical data (Dissolved Oxygen, pH, Turbidity, Specific Conductivity, and Water Temperature) at each sample collection were obtained with an YSI model 6920 V2-2 sonde (YSI, Yellow Springs, Ohio, USA). HOBO Pendant Data loggers (Onset Computer, Cape Cod, Massachusetts, USA) were also placed at each site on the stream bed, below water level, to continuously record hourly water temperature.

Laboratory Analysis: Anion concentrations (Br-, Cl-, F-, NO3-, NO2-, PO43- and SO42- ) were determined by a Dionex Ion Chromatography System (ICS)-1000, AS40 automated sampler (Dionex, Sunnyvale, California, USA), utilizing an AS9-HC anion column and a ASRS self-regulating suppressor. Retention times and ionic signatures were determined according to the Dionex Quality Assurance Report serial number 18487. Carbon concentrations (DOC, BDOC) were determined using an OI Analytical Aurora 1030/ Autosampler Model 1088 TOC analyzer (OI Analytical, College Station, Texas, USA). All internal calibration verifications (ICV) and continuous calibration verifications (CCV) were prepared using multi element or total organic carbon standards. Both ICV’s and CCV’s encompassing the concentration range of samples (0.1-10 mg/L) were included in each method of analysis. The latter were performed on every 15 samples to ensure reliability of the instrument. All standards, reagents, and field blanks were prepared with 18 mega-ohm water from a Barnstead Easy Pure II UV/UF water purification system (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, Massachusetts, USA). The detection limits of the Dionex ICS-1000 and OI Analytical TOC analyzer were approximately 0.01 mg/L.
